Igor Razvodovsky
Apr 6

Turning Spotify Into Jukebox

Sometimes the mood calls for a specific song. Some of these moments happen when you are outside — in a café, bookshop, laundromat or a pub. In the past people tried to solve it with jukebox machines. Today they have almost vanished from our life, but one still doesn't have any other means to listen to a song of one's choice while drinking coffee at the local coffee house.

At one point I realised that we have everything we need to make it happen. I have Spotify at my fingertips. Shops, restaurants and bars frequently use Spotify to play their music. How hard can it be to connect those two?

Disclaimer: I do not work for Spotify, and both the problem & the solution described below are merely the result of my speculation on the topic.

Jukebox gives users control over music in public spaces — cafés, restaurants, bars, laundromats, parks, etc.

Problem definition

User goals & business needs

First of all, I needed to check whether the problem is real. I discussed with my friends, family & co-workers music-related situations they had in public places & came up with a simple list of user goals:

  • Personalize experience by listening to your favourite music;
  • Support current mood with music;
  • Share a song with a friend;
  • Find out what is playing (just like Shazam/SoundHound).

Spotify already provides businesses with the instrument to control their music environment. Case studies from Soundtrack your brand helped to identify business needs. Those are:

  • Communicate brand identity through music choices;
  • Create ambience;
  • Comfort of all customers is equally important.

The main conclusion of user & business needs comparison was a contradiction between users' goal to listen to music of their choice and businesses' need to maintain the brand's image or ambience. User’s wish may differ greatly from the Place’s ambience. It needed to be taken into account.

Mental model & basic flow

Discussing the problem with potential users also helped to shape the mental model of how Jukebox should operate. Ordering a song should be similar to operating a jukebox or asking a waiter for something. The users should also understand that the order can be denied or that there can be a considerable waiting time.

User: Can I have a latte, please? 
Waiter: Anything else?
U: Yeah, can I ask for something comforting to listen to?
W: Of course, do you like Damien Rice? I Don’t Want To Change You will make your worries and cares go away.
U: Sure, that sounds fine.
W: OK, so that’s one latte and I Don’t Want To Change You by Damien Rice.
U: Thank You.

This dialog can be turned into a UI flow:

  1. User gets the notification about feature's availability.
  2. User opens the Place’s profile where user sees the current playlist and Pick a song call to action.
  3. After tapping user is presented with options to choose from — to either browse user's music or search in global catalogue or Place’s library.
  4. After the song is chosen it is placed in a queue.

Challenges

There were two big issues before I could move on with detailed sketching & prototyping:

  1. What format to use? Do it as part of Spotify app or as stand-alone application?
  2. The Place should be able to set boundaries to user’s choice. How?

What format to use?

How should it look like? Should it be a feature in the Spotify app or a stand-alone application? Simplicity and elegance of standalone app is tempting. I always liked the idea of “one task — one app”, but it will probably kill user acquisition. Not everyone is ready to install a new application for a single use. Statistics vary between 0 and 2 new app installs per month.

The feature in the main app caused another problem — inconsistency in interaction. Normally, a tap on a song in Spotify starts a playback. In Jukebox, on the other hand, a tap on a song should queue it for playback on an external system. To support such a difference in a single app, you need to make clear rules to the user. E.g.:

  1. User wants to listen to Death’s Diary by Marc Almond.
  2. User doesn’t remember the name of the song & searches by the name of the artist, then goes to artist's profile and finds the right song.
  3. What should happen when user taps on a song?

The logic of the scenario suggests to play it through a Jukebox, but the standard app logic — to play on the device. So when user leaves Jukeboxe’s designated section, it becomes unclear which pattern to use. There are two ways how to solve it.

ISOLATE or INTEGRATE?

First option was to isolate feature from the rest of the app. This means that the Jukebox is limited by its section and by leaving the section app returns to the regular rules.

This approach had several disadvantages, the main being the search. In order for a user to stay in the Jukebox, the search should take place on the spot, which meant functionality duplication and non-standard search behaviour. User won't be able to go from search results to artist, album or playlist & continue to search there.

Second option, to integrate feature seamlessly into the app, resembles Spotify Connect. Jukebox can be treated like external device. After you connect to it the app starts working differently. This sounds more like development of the existing functionality. But unlike regular external devices Jukebox is limited to only permitted music. It would be possible to navigate inside the app freely, but quite a lot of it will not be available due to Place's restrictions.

To sum it up, isolation would limit search capabilities, while integration will result in strangely looking app with disabled Radio & Browse sections & more. I didn't have the time to prototype & test both options, so I decided to go with more predictable one & isolated feature from the rest of the app.

How Place should limit user’s choice?

Primary users' goal is to listen to their favourite music. How realistic is this in a public place? Others could be opposed to you listening to Rammstein for a morning cup of coffee. Not every Place will allow you to play any kind of music. Cafés, bars or shops have different ambience and preferences when it comes to music. Many of them have a brand to upkeep. So each Place should be able to establish some rules. It can limit it's preferences in two ways.

1.STRICT

Music is pre-defined to genres, moods or playlists.

Genres, Moods or Tags
Like indie for a hipster cafe. There will be a default playlist (manually compiled or chosen from existing playlists), but customers will be able to put any song labeled as indie. The same goes for moods (based on Genres & Moods section of Browse feature) & any tags.

Playlists
A Place as well as any profile can have one or several playlists and users can choose a song to play next. It's the simplest solution.

2. RADIO

The problem with strict boundaries is that the rules are too rigid and don’t provide sufficient freedom of choice. Selecting within one playlist isn’t fun. It also applies to genres. For some Places indie will be too broad, while for the others too narrow and the related styles should be included.

So instead it is possible to build something similar to radio format. One or several Place’s playlists can serve as reference points to it and determine suitability of a particular song.

Scenarios

I wrote several scenarios to broaden the understanding of product's behaviour & test the assumptions within different contexts.

Result

Discovery & Entry points

We rarely choose a Place to go to based on music. So a need for the Jukebox will emerge only after the user has entered the Place. Feature's availability or perhaps even song suggestion would popup on the screen after user enters the Place.

In-app entry points

I also needed to place it somewhere within the app. A list of Places is located under Browse section. Also, there is a list of nearby Places on Home screen.

Place

From one of the entry points user goes to Place’s profile. Information about current playlist, Place’s musical preferences and big green button leading to Jukebox will be available there.

Jukebox

What one expects after tapping on Pick a song? The main task here is to clearly communicate place’s format to avoid misunderstanding in the process. Therefore, depending on a place user can either search for a particular tune or browse available playlists.

Match & Search

User can search for a song in two ways. He can either match his own library to the Place’s or search in the global library.

Chances are high that the song that user wants to listen to, is already added to his library. You & Place screen has a list of all songs Place & user share.

As for the search, there is difference between not found and not available song. The song can be in Spotify catalogue, but not available here & now. Even if the song isn't available it should appear in the results, so it would be clear that the search request is correct & no typos were made.

Ordering

Once a song is chosen, user needs to confirm it. Usually confirmation dialogs are a redundant step (possibility to cancel order would be sufficient), but here it helps to differentiate ordering from playback on the user's device once again. Also there is info about waiting time.

Voting

After the user has made a choice, the song is queued. Ok. The first song is added to the queue. What will happen after the second, third, etc? Adding a lot of songs to the queue will lead to a long wait, which can be controlled by voting.

Onboarding

Finally I needed to tell the users about Jukebox & how they can start using it. I made a walkthrough with general overview of the feature. It will present itself the first time user opens updated application. It covers basic interactions & ends with list of nearby places where user can try new feature.

It's also important to tell about the feature to non-users and users with disabled notifications. Leaflets on the tables or posters on the walls can do it.

Conclusion

As a longtime user, I have always appreciated how Spotify can support & enrich different moments of my day with music. Mood playlists for work & leisure, new finds from recommendations, Monday commutes with fresh Discover Weekly & much more. I think Jukebox could become a nice addition to these features & create it's own moments:

  • Mood, food & music pairing while dining out;
  • Sharing your favourite songs with friends while going out;
  • Choosing songs while riding a taxi or Uber;
  • Endless possibilities.

And even though I am aware that this is not a complete journey, that much more is yet to be done and more comprehensive research & testing are required, I think it has a potential.
